The research on which the empirical discussion is based draws on over two hundred in-depth interviews, over three hundred field observations, and a review of documentary data over the course of four years of data collection. Research focused on three mixed-income developments that are being built on the footprint of public housing complexes—Oakwood Shores, Park Boulevard, and Westhaven Park—that have been demolished as part of the CHA’s Plan for Transformation. Interviewees included residents across housing tenures (renters and owners in public housing, tax-credit subsidy or “affordable” units, and market-rate units) and key informants (including developers, property managers, service providers, CHA staff, housing advocates, and community organization leaders) at each site and operating at the city level. Interviews were guided by a semistructured interview instrument composed primarily of open-ended questions covering a core set of topics, with some specific variations targeted to particular interviewees based on their position and role. Observations included those of governance committees and community meetings, programs, events, and community interactions taking place in each site. Interviews were recorded digitally and transcribed in their entirety, and both interviews and fieldnotes were coded for analysis using the N’Vivo qualitative data analysis software program.

Initial policy requirements for one-for-one unit replacement have been waived, and the overall stock of public housing units will be reduced by about fourteen thousand units, with the intent to replace, in essence, only those units occupied (as opposed to those in existence) at the time of the announcement of the plan (Smith 2006; Hunt 2009).

These distinctions are not always exact, however, and there is significant overlap across the two literatures. (See Daly and Silver [2008] for a critical review and discussion of the relationship between these two constructs.) For example, much of the focus on “vertical ties” in the social capital literature—that is, relational linkages that connect individuals or collectivities to individual and institutional sources of information and opportunity that are so critical for fostering mobility—is similar to the assumptions that lie behind the conceptualization of social exclusion, in that the lack of such ties defines, in part, the state of social exclusion in which marginalized populations live. Similarly, both social capital and social exclusion literatures put forth social solidarity and social cohesion as crucially important for alleviating the problems of marginalization, yet these literatures often point to different means—most importantly different enabling institutions—to achieve these goals. For example, in policymaking, states that predominantly invoke social capital rhetoric tend to promote nonstate policy solutions to marginalization—relying on nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), for example—to encourage expanded networks and varying interactions and exchanges, whereas states that adopt a social exclusion lens tend to promote more state-initiated responses that reflect a presumed societal responsibility to build an “inclusive” society. Perhaps ironically, although state-initiated, the reforms that are actually generated from a social exclusion discourse with the broader context of neoliberalism nevertheless take on many of the same properties of those closely associated with social capital generation, including the invocation of “civil society” and the use of community and voluntary organizations to shape and implement interventions. This is increasingly the case in the context of fiscal austerity adopted by some states in response to the economic downturn beginning in 2008, with a concomitant withdrawal of state-led efforts in favor of voluntary-sector responses.

In the wake of Labour’s loss of power in the 2010 elections and in the context of the current austerity response to the economic downturn beginning in 2008, of course, these solutions have been largely abandoned, replaced by the “Big Society” framework championed by David Cameron.
A more detailed analysis of these strategies and responses to community building efforts in these mixed-income developments can be found in Chaskin and Joseph (2010).

Although race is a critical factor in shaping the history of public housing in Chicago and the social and political dynamics surrounding its reform, it plays out in different and sometimes complex ways in different mixed-income sites. In sites with greater ethnic diversity among owners, race often operates as a salient marker of difference and serves as a proxy for shaping assumptions about owner versus renter status among their neighbors. In sites where most owners are also African American, these dynamics are somewhat more complicated.
Relocated public housing resident interview, October 18, 2007.
A more in-depth analysis of these issues and how they are playing out in mixed-income developments that are replacing public housing complexes can be found in Chaskin and Joseph (2012).
Relocated public housing resident interview, April 15, 2009.
For a more in-depth analysis of the deliberative mechanisms and processes in the mixed-income communities reviewed here, see Chaskin, Khare, and Joseph (2012).

bio.p: Robert J. Chaskin is an associate professor and deputy dean for strategic initiatives at the University of Chicago School of Social Service Administration. His work focuses on conceptual foundations and principal strategies of contemporary community intervention in the context of urban poverty. He has written widely on the topics of neighborhood intervention, community capacity building, and the dynamics of participatory planning and neighborhood governance.
